Thus f...
entry.content:
æˆ‘çœ‹äº†ä¸€ä¸‹è‹±æ–‡ç‰ˆå’Œä¸­æ–‡å¯¹ç…§ï¼Œé¡ºä¾¿è¡¥å……ä¸€ä¸‹åšä¸»é—æ¼ä¸­è‹±æ–‡ä¸ä¸€è‡´çš„åœ°æ–¹å§ï¼ˆç”¨ã€ã€‘è¡¨ç¤ºï¼‰ã€‚

Thus far, China has not tried to overthrow but rather to increase its influence within the world order from which it benefits, but this could change as Chinese power grows.(17) ã€Appetites sometimes grow with eating, and Xi Jinping's rhetoric about China as a great state suggests this could occur.ã€‘ The Trump administration has called China a revisionist power, but so far its revisionism has been quite moderate, unlike extreme revisionist powers such as Hitler's Germany. China is not interested in kicking over the card table but in tilting the table so it can claim a larger share of the winnings. China's growing economic power will create problems for the United States and the international order, and this friction will likely continue. The United States will have to manage alliances, networks, and institutions deftly to shape the environment in which China uses its growing power.
